image.altText: Leanne wears a blazer and dress, gesturing while speaking to media.

props.synopsis: Leanne Castley is elected leader of the Canberra Liberals, following the party's defeat at the ACT election.

title.children: Leanne Castley elected leader of the Canberra Liberals as Elizabeth Lee says she was 'assured of support'

image.altText: ACT Supreme Court, Magistrates Court, building, generic

props.synopsis: The boy received a suspended sentence and good behaviour bond after a judge found he had demonstrated a degree of remorse.

title.children: Canberra school boy who raped 14-year-old girl avoids jail

image.altText: CCTV footage shows 'targeted' vandalism and theft at Canberra Hindu temple

props.synopsis: This is not the first time the buildings have been targeted by thieves and some community members say they are "horrified".

title.children: Two Hindu temples burgled, vandalised in broad daylight in Canberra

image.altText: A man wearing a chef's outfit stands behind a bar in front of many bottles of wine.

props.synopsis: An increasing number of Canberra restaurants are closing their doors, and the next 12 months is expected to get even worse.

title.children: Damien has already seen many colleagues close their restaurants, but says the next 12 months 'could be disastrous'

image.altText: An older man in a red shirt standing in front of a tree

props.synopsis: When spraying crops, John O'Brien would end up covered in chemicals including paraquat. He's one of six farmers from Crookwell who say they have been diagnosed with Parkinson's Disease.

title.children: Six farmers who grew up in the same town near Goulburn getting 'covered' in chemicals now all have Parkinson's

props.synopsis: Last year the ACT became the first Australian jurisdiction to decriminalise small amounts of illicit drugs. One year on, what has happened in the territory?

title.children: Small amounts of drugs were decriminalised in the ACT, but it didn't turn Canberra into our 'party capital'

image.altText: Black gloves hold a pink vape in its packaging.

props.synopsis: Two Canberra men face the ACT Magistrates Court after they were arrested in a police sting targeting the trade in illegal vapes.

title.children: Two men facing charges after allegedly being caught with thousands of vapes and cash in Canberra

image.altText: A man standing in a workshop holds a wooden box closed.

props.synopsis: After years of collecting beautiful pieces of timber, Australian woodworker Scott Mitchell couldn't believe it when he was asked to craft part of a gift for King Charles III.

title.children: Meet the Australian woodworker who crafted a box fit for a king

image.altText: Several plastic bags filled with gold coins outside a storage locker.

props.synopsis: Police allege a women charged with the theft of 63,000 limited edition Bluey coins earlier this year was the getaway driver. The 27-year-old Western Sydney woman is the third person to be arrested for the theft as 40,000 of the missing coins were discovered.

title.children: Police find more than 40,000 stolen Bluey coins in storage facility months after robbery

image.altText: Red, blue and white cars and vans seen submerged in muddy floodwaters

props.synopsis: Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez has warned there may be more dangerous weather to come and urged residents to take extreme precautions for their own safety.

title.children: Spain declares three days of mourning after at least 95 people killed in flash flooding disaster

image.altText: A person holds a Woolworths-branded brown paper shopping bag while walking through the fresh produce section.

props.synopsis: Woolworths has its annual general meeting today, while Coles is posting a trading update. Meanwhile, the Australian share market is trading slightly down as hopes for a pre-Christmas interest rate cut fade. Follow live.

title.children: Woolworths grilled by investors, as its rival Coles tells the market that inflation is coming down

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Is Australia on the cusp of its next building boom?
ASX falls deepen as miners, supermarkets and banks all weigh
Broker downgrade sends AGL shares tumbling

image.altText: The outside of a court building. A sign says "Supreme Court".

props.synopsis: An investigation into the government care provided to a 12-year-old girl who was charged with murder over a brutal stabbing last year has found failings in every aspect of her protection.

title.children: Case of 12-year-old charged with woman's murder revealed 'tragic' child protection failures, report finds

image.altText: Cars piled up after a flood

props.synopsis: Spain's flash floods were caused by a destructive weather system in which cold and warm air meet and produce powerful rain clouds, a pattern believed to be becoming more prevalent due to climate change.

title.children: What caused Spain's deadliest floods in decades?

image.altText: Composite picture of Angus Taylor, Michele Bullock and Jim Chalmers.

props.synopsis: What, or more precisely who, is to blame for the inflation episode that has up-ended our lives for the past three years?

title.children: It's finger-pointing time on Australia's 'homegrown' inflation problem

image.altText: Syrenite smiles at the camera.

props.synopsis: Child health and wellbeing researchers have welcomed an independent review criticising the COVID-19 pandemic response in relation to young people.

title.children: This Victorian teenager still experiences social anxiety since the pandemic, and an inquiry has found she's not alone

image.altText: Two white women in hats and sunglasses standing smiling on a dirt path

props.synopsis: Patients have told ABC NEWS they're concerned about a lack of informed consent over Australia's most common osteoporosis drug, and are sometimes "scared into" taking it.

title.children: It's a common osteoporosis drug – but some patients say they're not being warned enough about side effects

image.altText: A 3D model showing three Iron Dome components. A radar, a missile launcer and a command centre.

props.synopsis: Since its deployment in 2011, the Iron Dome has become a signature weapon in Israel’s armoury. A barrage of modern weaponry from Iran and its proxies is testing its limits.

title.children: A look inside the sophisticated attacks breaking through Israel's anti-missile systems

image.altText: Smoke billowing over a town in the Middle East following an airstrike.

props.synopsis: Lebanon's Prime Minister Najib Mikati says he is "optimistic" that Israel and Lebanon could agree to a ceasefire in the "coming hours or days".

title.children: Lebanon and Israel could agree to ceasefire 'in coming days', says Lebanese PM

image.altText: HMAS Warramunga at sea.

props.synopsis: The HMAS Warramunga diverts its course to come to the aid of woman in her 50s thought to have been bitten be shark while was snorkelling off a boat yesterday afternoon.

title.children: Woman rescued by the Navy after a suspected shark attack 10 hours off coast of Mackay

image.altText: Two young people with a box of groceries

props.synopsis: A CHOICE investigation across four remote First Nations communities has found grocery items cost more than double capital city prices, with calls for the federal government to introduce price monitoring tools and price caps on essentials.

title.children: 'Mystery shoppers' visited four Indigenous communities and found a 'stark' difference in prices for essentials

image.altText: A close-up of Kamala Harris speaking, taken from the side, with a blue sky background.

props.synopsis: Kamala Harris attempts to distance herself from Joe Biden's comments about Donald Trump's supporters, which have attracted backlash in the final days of the campaign.

title.children: Harris 'strongly disagrees' with criticising voters after Biden's 'garbage' remark

image.altText: A man with a neutral expression looks on.

props.synopsis: When a German researcher arrived in Yuendumu in 1972, the Indigenous community gave him rare access to their customs and culture. Half a century later, an emotional reunion has seen some sacred artefacts he was given returned.

title.children: These sacred artefacts were thought lost forever, but one phone call changed everything

image.altText: Tennis player Alexei Popyrin shouts up at the chair umpire during a match at the Paris Masters.

props.synopsis: A late line call gets Alexei Popyrin's blood boiling, but he regains his composure to take down world number five Daniil Medvedev, while compatriot Alex de Minaur takes another step towards a maiden ATP Finals berth.

title.children: 'I don't wanna play': Aussie Popyrin recovers after foul-mouthed tirade to take down Medvedev

image.altText: PMs courtyard, man talking, smiling

props.synopsis: The prime minister has had little to celebrate in recent weeks. But a close look at the inflation data could open up a dream scenario for the next election.

title.children: A pair of rate cuts could find Albanese 'kicking with the wind' to an April election

image.altText: Woman in office with glasses on staring deadpan at camera

props.synopsis: NSW Premier Chris Minns has apologised after several local stakeholders, including the mayor, were not told about a drug summit being held in Griffith tomorrow.

title.children: Anger at 'whoever's running' NSW drug summit as key local groups and leaders not invited

image.altText: A man sits on a couch holding a ball for his large dog.

props.synopsis: Students coming into the country from overseas struggle to access accommodation, especially without rental and employment history, but housing developments near campuses have faced opposition from some councils and colleges, including Sydney's prestigious acting school NIDA.

title.children: 'Cash cows milked by the system': International students on the frontline of housing crisis

image.altText: A black and white self portrait - a short haired woman wearing a vest stares into an old Box Brownie camera

props.synopsis: Edna Walling was one of Australia's most influential garden designers, known for her use of low stone walls, meandering pathways and self-seeding plants.

title.children: Edna Walling designed gardens for the Murdoch and Packer families, and she remains Australian gardening royalty

image.altText: Pat Conroy press club

props.synopsis: A former defence employee at the centre of a corruption scandal has now left a French-owned weapons company that has just been awarded a lucrative munitions contract by the Albanese government.

title.children: Thales Australia clinches government munitions deal after company stops hiring employee accused of corruption

image.altText: A close shot of Brereton, who is sitting in the offices of the new national anti--corruption commission

props.synopsis: The head of the anti-corruption watchdog is facing calls to step aside following a review into a decision to not investigate Robodebt referrals.

title.children: National anti-corruption watchdog chief's future in question after Robodebt decision

image.altText: Image of a tadpole fossil.

props.synopsis: Researchers have discovered the oldest-known tadpole reported to date, a fossil from 161 million years ago found in Argentina. The discovery sheds light on the evolution of frogs and toads.

title.children: 'It's like a Mona Lisa': Giant Jurassic tadpole fossil includes skeleton, nerves and eyes

image.altText: A woman with short black hair and wearing a black dress stands before a press junket speaking.

props.synopsis: Kate Seselja lost $500,000 during her gambling addiction. She questions if the NSW government's new peer support service goes far enough to address gambling harm.

title.children: Kate gambled away $500k. When she called a support line, the advice she received was far from helpful

image.altText: A boy and his dad smiling together while on a mountain.

props.synopsis: The hit-run crash death of the youngest son of South Australia's top cop gripped South Australians, who grieved the 18-year-old "widely and deeply".

title.children: The night that changed the lives of two young men and their families

image.altText: An older man leans on a car to pose for a photo wearing a blue flowery shirt.

props.synopsis: RACQ has suffered a massive complaints spike, as premiums triple and insurance claims are mishandled so badly that repair contractors robbed a customer.

title.children: 'RACQ has lost the plot': What's bedevilling one of Queensland's most high-profile companies?

image.altText: A scary clown at Exmouth Halloween in October 2024.

props.synopsis: A secretive military history, a defence science facility, and a haunted house. Exmouth has all the makings of a good scary movie.

title.children: This remote WA town has celebrated Halloween for decades thanks to its military past
